main_text:
Galileo Galilei (1564–1642) has always played a key role in any
history of science, as well as many histories of philosophy. He is
a—if not the—central figure of the Scientific
Revolution of the seventeenth century. His work in physics (or
“natural philosophy”), astronomy, and the methodology of
science still evoke debate after more than 400 years. His role in
promoting the Copernican theory and his travails and trials with the
Roman Church are stories that still require re-telling. This article
attempts to provide an overview of these aspects of Galileo’s
life and work, but does so by focusing in a new way on his arguments
concerning the nature of matter.
